Posts.Content: On the same subject I am having a DIEP next Thursday.  I've bought, as advised a sort of 2spanks/corset things as advised by Southmead. T  Do I wear knickers or something as well?
Posts.Title: Post operation underwear

Posts.Content: Hi I'm having a DIEP but like you I've been told I have very little fat and will be an A possibly B.   Currently a DD.     Were you happy with your outcome in the end?
Posts.Title: DIEP after C-Sections

Posts.Content: You're not alone.  I too am at the bottom of the mountain, scared witless.   We don't have any choice but to run.  I hope you beat that lion  Xx
Posts.Title: Something I’d like to share

Posts.Content: Well done you.  Sounds like you and I had similar experiences.   I can see why people give up on the cap but for me it will depend on how much hair it helps me keep.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi 8uttercup Glad I'm not the only one not working.  I had a double mx with DIEP reconstruction in Feb and 1st FEC last Thursday.   Have to say I just wouldn't have had the energy to work, even part time really.  I've had a couple of energetic days and I haven't just been sitting about but I'm so tired that I fall asleep when I stop.   My job is one that needs some concentration and is safety related so happily my company would rather I be off than there making mistakes. Feel a bit of a failure when I read of ladies who manage to keep working.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Loubag Don't know if this is any help but in our very early thirties my husband was disabled overnight with MS.  Never had a symptom before.  I was a stay at home Mum to our 2 year old.  We'd been playing at property development and were in the middle of doing one house up.  Shortly after the economy crashed, interest rates went to 15%, our properties dropped in value and our mortgage was horrendous.  I suddenly was propelled back into the workplace. Working full-time as well as trying to look after a toddler and hubby, who by the way lost his job through his illness so no other income, was very difficult.  During that period we accumulated more debt.    It took a long time to get right but we did it.  If forced me to become much more active in my job and then career choices.    We used enjoy having sausages with a roast.  We couldn't afford to go out but we learned to make more of little things. We completely recovered financially  (and we've been very careful of debt since).  My husband never went back to work again but is ok.  We had another child, been very happy, paid the mortgage off etc. So in my long winded way I'm  trying to say not to worry.  Your treatment is temporary, you will recover and you can help restore financial security when you're better.    If there are opportunities for you to identify where you can cut some corners financially now then do so.    I managed to renegotiate some of our payments to help during that period.  Good luck to you and big hug to you and hubby during this testing time.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Coll  Ditto Tibi  It was my first FEC 16 days ago and I took a paracetamol before hand.  I'd say for me it took 30 minutes before it became easy to tolerate.  I made sure my scalp was completely wet and I had the cap on tight (too tight really, had a headache for days after) because I was mad keen for it to be in contact.  I refused hot drinks and sucked on frozen ice pops and I haven't had any problems with my mouth.   I've since washed my hair infrequently using the Simple range of hair products.  No hairdryer or styling tools and only use a wide toothed cimb from Wilkinson's.    I know it's early days but head hair is still ok despite losing hair elsewhere. Good luck!
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Thank you for the tips Ruby Rose much appreciated
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Morning YoungandFit  Your response is exactly the one I'm hoping for.  Thank you. At an appt recently one cheerful soul proceeded to enlighten me on all the suffering she'd been though from it, how her husband had left her during it and then lectured my husband on all the duties he'd need to pick up in support of me. Rather unnecessary as I already have a grim awareness of the worst I might face.  Also, as my husband has been retired for years while I've been working, I've already taken on the role of Cleopatra  (she who deems to be bathed in asses milk or as hubby affectionately calls me 'lazy mare") and he is well used to taking responsibility for all things domestic. Unfortunately whilst at 59 I have the height and frame of a more athletic person it is completely misleading and Idon't have a strong constitution so I'm bracing myself for a difficult time but hoping for better.   If I come out of it saying the same as you I will be well pleased.   Thank you also for the comment on 'gold standard.  I will use that as an anchor to hang on to if I ever feel like giving it up. How were your hair and nails through it all?
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Thank you ladies.  The lovely chemo nurse made it as pleasant as possible.  The most uncomfortable bit being the cold cap but I stuck with it and got used to it.  Made them laugh because I kept using my spare hand to push it even closer. Since being home at 3 my tum has felt very slightly churney but I've been out with the dog for 40 mins and now had a 2 hour nap.   Husband got a hard look and a big fat no when he answered last child's, age 21, question about when dinner would be ready with mum will probably put it on at 6.30.   Yes it was just adding some cooked meat, and a jar of sauce to pasta and steaming some beans but really.   To be fair hubby does cook a lot but even sonny looked surprised too and was readily agreeable to preparing his own.  Hubby has now prepared ours on return from the gym.   Think I've just established food protocol for chemo day.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Debbie Ditto what Dormouse said.  After my first FEC chemo my nurse said to absolutely not put up with any vomiting or extreme nausea.  She said to phone immediately if that happened as the quicker they know the quicker they can help you.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Loubag. No I'm exactly the same and on day 6 like you.  I am thinking it's the neutrophils dropping.  I have antibiotics to start tomorrow, have you?
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Thank you Gay nice to hear.  Yesterday a lady at the hospital insisted on telling me it was the pits and instructing my husband of my care.  Have to say I get everything going and don't react well to medicines so expecting the worst and hoping for the best or at least your experience.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Rather unnecessary as I already have a grim awareness of the worst I might face.  Also, as my husband has been retired for years while I've been working, I've already taken on the role of Cleopatra  (she who deems to be bathed in asses milk or as hubby affectionately calls me 'lazy mare') and he is well used to taking responsibility for all things domestic. Posts.Content: Good luck!
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hoping you're well and out in no time.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah  Bad luck for having to join our club.  I had my first FEC last week and had simular symptoms.  I took Gaviscon to settle my tum which helped with uneasiness.  I use the non alcohol Corsydil several times a day BUT i dilute it with water which makes it go further and is more palatable and I find ice pops pleasant.   Good luck.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Loubag,   I'm not having weekly chemo but after my first FEC recently I had an episode  of feeling fed up, that I just didn't want to be doing this and that I'm going to be one of those girls where TNBC appears later as secondarys.  Don't know where it all came from because I'm usually very positive.  I think it was the physical affect of the chemicals depressing my body.   Feeling more on top now. However chemo and symptoms keeping you awake it's not surprising you might feel a bit gloomy.  Especially as the trial you are on looks like a tough regime.  However I'd really like to be having what you're on because I reckon that combination is going to be lethal for TNBC and will really kick it out of your system.   Those are effective chemicals and I'd feel much more confident that I wouldn't be seeing this cancer again.   Try and take as much help as you can get to get though it. I hope you wake this morning feeling better.   Big hug to you. X
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: I've had a headache on and off but I think mine was from having the cold cap on too tight.  I insisted and claimed it was ok when I knew it could have been a bit looser.   It's day 12 so this weekend when I'm away is when I might shed.  Have already picked a scarf to wrap my head in just in case.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Sorry you missed your birthday and hope you're feeling better now.   I'm curious to know what they actually do to you in that situation?  If you don't mind sharing?
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Tibu315 Gosh that was a reassuring response.   Hope all goes well from here forward. X Violet25
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi  I've recently been diagnosed with TNBC grade 3 in my right breast  and because of family history am opting for a double mastectomy and ovraectomy. My am tall, broad chested and currently spilling out of a double D bra but the size suits my build. I am leaning towards a DIEP because I suspect my body will reject an artificial substance. However my plastic surgeon has said that he will not be able to achieve the size I've got now and am looking at between an A and B cup. Has anyone else had to reduce like this?  Ideally I'd love to see pictures of people who are properly healed from this op, and WITHOUT tattoos hiding the result.  All the pictures I'm finding are ones not long after when the scars are still angry looking. I want to make a thought out decision that will be able to live with without regret in the future
Posts.Title: DIEP resulting in smaller boobs than before

Posts.Content: Thank you Carolyn.   It is difficult to find before and after photos of someone who has a bilateral reconstruction but who has had to go smaller.   I appreciate you trying.
Posts.Title: DIEP resulting in smaller boobs than before

Posts.Content: Dear Hazel66 Thank you so so much for responding.  I would very much appreciate seeing your photos as long as you are happy to share them with me.   I  am in such a quandary about how to move forward that it's beginning to get me down.  I've managed to get to my late 50s having had children and still keep a fairly firm blemish free tum and boobs.  I still wear skimpy bikinis to sunbathe in but  I'm definitely  no glamour puss more your bohemian gran.   My boobs may be DD but I'm very broad chested so they are wider rather than just full fronted.   At the end if the day I'm comfortable in this skin and with what I see in the mirror and have never harboured and desire to change. Ive been lucky. I'm now mourning the body I'm about to lose and getting in quite a state.  Even recognising I'm doing this to try and survive is not consoling me much. I'd be happy for a D or C cup but I'm not sure about less on me.  Being tall and broad seeing the outline of boobs feminises my shape - which is what I like. Sorry to ramble on so much.
Posts.Title: DIEP resulting in smaller boobs than before

Posts.Content: Thank you Carolyn x
Posts.Title: DIEP resulting in smaller boobs than before

Posts.Content: MRI proved it wasn't mechanical or cancer.  So I was prescribed Oramorph.  Only took it that night. It made me tired but didn't completely mask the pain.  The next morning I was so nauseous I spent the day throwing up.  Difficult because it was my chemo talk morning.  I've now been given anti nausea tablets which are helping although the nausea keeps coming back in between despite my stopping the Oramorph.  Happily today I'm seeing my plastics team who are hoping to get a physio to help me.  Can't wait.
Posts.Title: Back spasms 9 weeks after DIEP

Posts.Content: Hi all I haven't started chemo yet so that's not the cause.  I spoke to my plastics nurse who I'm seeing Friday and she said that if it was still a problem she might be able to arrange a physio but meanwhile to see my Dr. Upshot is I saw Dr this morning, who spoke to Oncology and I am now sitting in Oncology waiting for a MRI to rule out cancer as the cause.  Fingers crossed it proves to be muscle spasm.
Posts.Title: Back spasms 9 weeks after DIEP

Posts.Content: Desperately need advice.  I had a double mastectomy and DIEP about 9 weeks ago. However a couple of weeks ago I woke in the night with my back aching around the bra line.  Took some painkillers and went back to sleep. Fast forward and it's awful.  I get 2 hours sleep max.  It was easing off in the day but not so much today. I've tried my husband's Tramadol and Naproxen at night but they don't help.  Neither do Ibuprofen or Paracetamol.    I'm getting spasms so bad they make breathing and swallowing painful and I find myself crying out involuntarily, the pain is so bad.  Last night we were staying in a hotel after a wedding and I have spent most of the night on the bathroom floor trying out different exercises in an attempt to address it. I'm certain the solution will be exercises. Anyone else had this problem and have advice to offer please? I'm getting desperate.
Posts.Title: Back spasms 9 weeks after DIEP
